@jimmysong @morcosa @TuurDemeester @naval Perhaps a few students got interested and started working on it, which in and of itself is cool. \n\nBitcoin had also already been established to an extent and had a longer term market value, so it's not entirely analogous to airdrops of new coins.

@jimmysong @morcosa @TuurDemeester @naval Would love to see a follow-up study on it on the longer term effects. Hard to discern correlation from causation.\n\nFrom a friend who just spoke to an MIT alum about it: "She doesn't know anyone who did anything aside from sell it at some point"
@paul_btc @TuurDemeester @naval @_jillruth Ah, I'm defining a "faircoin" as an asset that is equally given to everyone in the world from the start, or some variation of that.

@morcosa @TuurDemeester @naval I'm not saying it was a complete and utter failure. I'm reflecting on recent conversations with friends from MIT about what happened with it (including an MIT alum on our team)! :)

@TuurDemeester @naval To quote @_jillruth "The whole model totally misses the fact that money is construed value based solely on people’s perceptions."\n\nWhile "faircoins" may sound nice, it's unlikely they'll actually be as fair as they sound. /Fin

@TuurDemeester @naval Tl;dr Human perceptions of value matter. If people don't value something, they won't keep it, and airdrops of new assets tend to result in the power law distributions we see in existing monetary systems.

@TuurDemeester @naval "Nevertheless, contrary to the government's expectations [that vouchers would mean a more equitable distribution not concentrated in the hands of the mafia and elites], insiders managed to acquire control over most of the assets..."

@TuurDemeester @naval (3) And I'd really like to do more research on this one: airdrops of vouchers in Russia in the 90s as companies privatized. Big companies came in and swept these up for cheap from citizens who didn't value them. https://t.co/5JX4SUr9XU

@TuurDemeester @naval That's from information I've been able to gather by asking around, it didn't jumpstart some huge revolution in development as some had hoped. This study says 50% say they held by 2017, but I'm wondering how many still have access. :) https://t.co/5Y1UoHKfxn

@TuurDemeester @naval (2) MIT Bitcoin project airdrop in 2014. Every MIT student got free $100 of bitcoin, awesome! Turns out most students sold pretty soon thereafter, lost the keys, used it to buy various substances, etc.

@TuurDemeester @naval Not surprisingly, the people on Mechnical Turk didn't value the STR, and the people who paid them ended up accumulating large sums of it, ending up in an inequitable distribution after all.

@TuurDemeester @naval One needed a facebook account to authenticate. Lo and behold, what did numerous enterprising individuals do? Went to Mechnical Turk, paid people cents to authenticate and get their ~$10 worth of STR.
@TuurDemeester @naval Let's look at some recent examples of "faircoins." (1) Stellar airdrop in August 2014. I signed up for it on the first day, July 31, 2014. Got my free STR.

As the world moves toward greater adoption of bitcoin and cryptocurrency, we're going to have to redesign and rethink the security of structures around us. Private keys representing money requires entirely different threat models.
It exposes the lack of secure infrastructure in many of the areas around us, e.g. in mobile phone companies and their insecure practices that allow for phone porting attacks.
Cryptocurrency is one of *the* most adversarial environments out there, because attackers can get access to actual money (as opposed to, say, personal data which they could use to get money).
The first rule of cryptocurrency security is if it can be stolen, it will be stolen.\n\nhttps://t.co/2q4qNSgLg7

@amredman @morcosa In a normal case it should be nearly instantly reallocated between channels.

@rdaros You still have to use on-chain txs to open channels, and nodes will go offline and you will need to close on-chain. There will be miner fees for all of these on-chain txs. LN is secured by the underlying blockchain, you have to go to the chain to resolve disputes.
@amredman @morcosa Obviously you can choose how much money you'd want to put in a channel, but anyone with more than one channel open can function as a node.

@davidgerard 7. But instead of doing actual research about the progress LN devs have made, it's a lot easier to not bother and complain instead.\n\nHaters gonna hate. Builders gonna build. I'd much rather be building real technology that solves real problems. /fin 🤷🏻‍♀️

@davidgerard 6. Routing is all automated and built in. The software just calculates the route and send the payment. If anyone along the path can't forward, the payment rolls back and a different route is tried. All within seconds or less.
@flibbr @drwasho It's there because it's still early software. Better to have multiple channels than one huge one.

@davidgerard 5. Anti-LN proponents keep asserting that the network will evolve to some theoretical super centralized model, even though our current graph is scale-free (aka distributed), much like how the internet is a scale-free nework. https://t.co/49xAHX6wUc

@davidgerard 4b. Nope. We'll use something like existing internet routing protocols where the nodes know some of the higher-level routes, and more details about "neighborhoods." None of these paths decrease privacy from the already onion-routed, private point we're at now.

@davidgerard 4a. We use onion routing privacy technology. Having a map of the network doesn’t allow you to track who is paying whom. An intermediate node doesn't know which hop it is on the network, and doesn't know about other nodes aside from the ones directly before or after.

@davidgerard 3. If the other side drops off, you have a timeout period that is a configurable parameter. We typically say it should be set for several days for security reasons in case a counterparty tries to cheat. It can be shorter or longer though.

@davidgerard 2. To use a payment channel, you have to commit the funds you plan to use for that channel/use case (or none if receiving). You can always open another one, and we expect people to have several.

@davidgerard 1. We have hundreds of awesome volunteer testers that have been testing out our LND implementation. We demoed 2 real bitcoin transactions between 3 implementations just last week. https://t.co/wTqI4uKhkd
